Review Metal-organic frameworks for electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide: The role of metal centers Ping Shao a Luocai Yi a Shumei Chen b Tianhua Zhou a ⁎ Jian Zhang a a State Key Laboratory of Structural Chemistry, Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Fuzhou 350002, Fujian, China State Key Laboratory of Structural Chemistry Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences Fuzhou Fujian 350002 China b College of Chemistry, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350002, Fujian, China College of Chemistry Fuzhou University Fuzhou Fujian 350002 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Direct electrochemical reduction of CO2 into valuable chemicals and fuel is one of the most promising approaches to address the current energy crisis and lower CO2 emission. Recently, numerous metal-organic framework (MOF) and their derived materials have extensively been developed as electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction owing to their unique structure including porosity, large specific surface area, and tunable chemical structures. In this review, the recent progress of MOF-based electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction was summarized and discussed. Detailed discussions mainly focus on the synthesis and mechanism of pristine MOFs and MOF-derived materials for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. These examples are expected to provide clues to rational design and synthesis of stable and high-performance MOFs-based electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction. Graphical abstract In this review, the effect of metal centers in metal-organic framework-based electrocatalysts on the performance of CO2 reduction was summarized and discussed. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal organic framework Electrocatalyst Carbon dioxides Reduction reaction Nanomaterials 1 Introduction There is a growing awareness of the severe environmental problem associated with the use of foil fuel, which has caused a large amount of CO2 emission and global climate change [1–7]. To address this issue, various greenhouse gas reduction strategies are developed. Short-term greenhouse gas reduction strategies are likely to improve the current energy supply, such as cogeneration and combined cycle gas turbines, and enhanced efficiencies of coal-based systems. In the long-term, however, energy efficiency and renewable will become a crucial part of the energy supply and use, which will effectively reduce the CO2 emission. One promising measure is the development of CO2 capture and conversion, including biomass, physical, and chemical solutions [8–11]. Nevertheless, CO2 capture not only consumes a lot of energy and costs, but also is easy to reach the capacity limits [5]. Accordingly, chemical conversion could be an ideal solution, which not only reduces CO2 emission but also produces valuable chemicals [12–15]. A promising way of atmospheric CO2 conversion is to catalyze the chemical reduction of CO2 to useful chemicals, such as carbon monoxide, methane, formic acid, ethane, ethylene [16–23]. In the past decades, various CO2 reduction approaches have been developed, including electrocatalytic reduction [24–30], photocatalytic reduction [31–41], chemical and biochemical reduction [42]. Among these methods, electrocatalytic reduction CO2 as a promising method has attracted the wide attention of researchers, since it can not only be conducted in ambient conditions, but also can be driven by renewable energy (e.g., solar, wind, and tide) [2,43]. However, extremely stable chemical structure of CO2 molecule requires large kinetic and thermodynamic energy barrier to be overcome to finish the reduction of CO2. However, chemical conversion of CO2 involves multiple-electron and proton transfer. The process presents many complex intermediates, which determines the reaction pathway and the selectivity as well as Faradaic efficiency of the products [27,44,45]. The activity and selectivity of the catalysts depend on the number of surface active site, atom distribution, surface electronic structure, coordination geometry, and chemical composition of catalysts [46]. Therefore, rational design and synthesis of high-performance electrocatalysts is of great importance for elucidating the relationship between catalyst structure and the reaction mechanism. To this end, it is crucial for the creation of well-defined catalysts with tunable structure. As a class of porous materials, MOFs are constructed by self-assembly of metal ions or clusters and organic ligand [47–55]. They can be prepared through rational design including pre-assembly [56] and post-synthesis modification method [57,58] to realize specific functional applications [59]. Compared with homogeneous molecular catalysts, MOF materials possess the recyclability of heterogeneous crystalline catalysts and permanent porosity. On the other hand, compared with conventional inorganic porous materials, MOF-based materials are well-defined crystalline materials with highly periodic arrangements of the organic ligands and metal nodes. Furthermore, their physical and chemical properties can be regulated by tuning the composition, metal node and organic ligand at the molecular level. These advantages make them attractive porous materials for application in gas capture and separation, heterogeneous catalysis, sensing and drug delivery [60–65]. Especially, MOF-based materials have attracted growing interests in the field of energy conversion and storage including photo- and electrocatalytic water splitting, and CO2 reduction [36,38,59,66–70]. However, poor electronic conductivity and structure stability of pristine MOFs to some extend hamper their direct application as electrocatalysts. Subsequently, the pristine MOFs have been used as promising precursor/templates to prepare MOF-derived porous nanomaterials including metal nanoparticle or single atom encapsulated in-situ formed carbon hybrid and metal-free nanocarbon for electrocatalysis applications [71–74]. Recent studies indicate that these MOF derivatives show obvious excellent performance for application in energy conversion and storage such as hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), supercapacitors, and lithium-ion Batteries [36,59,66–69]. In this review, we have systematically summarized current progress of MOF-based materials for electrocatalysis reduction of CO2. Although a few of reviews have described MOFs for photo- and electro-catalytic CO2 conversion [43–45,60–62,75–78], these reviews mainly focused on the pristine MOFs for reduction of CO2. We mainly focus on discussing the recent progresses of MOF composites (e.g. carbon nitride, graphene, carbon nanotube-containing MOF materials) and MOF-derived metal nanoparticles as well as single-atom catalysts for electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. The relationships between synthetic methods, different metal centers and the electrocatalytic performance for CO2 reduction have also been considered. Especially, how the metal center of the MOF-based materials influences the selectivity and activity of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. We hope these examples can provide predictive guidance for the rational design and synthesis of high-performance electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction. 2 Mechanism of electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 Electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 as a kind of promising way to convert CO2 into value-added fuel, has attracted the wide attention of researchers. Generally, the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 is performed in aqueous electrolytes, in a two-compartment three-electrode system. As shown in Scheme 1 , the reduction of CO2 occurs in the cathode compartment, the anode compartment is generally coupled to the oxygen evolution reaction [62,79], and the cathode compartments are separated from the anode by Nafion proton exchange membrane. The cathode compartment consists of working electrode and reference electrode (Ag/AgCl), while the anode compartment is composed of counter electrode (Platinum plate or net). Electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 is multi-electron and -proton reduction reaction involving a number of different surface reaction intermediates. As a result, there are a large number of possible reduction productions, including hydrogen, carbon monoxide, formaldehyde, formic acid, methane, methanol, and ethene, through two, four, six, eight, and twelve-electron reduction in aqueous solution. Their reduction potential reference to standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) at pH7 are shown in the following Eqs. (1)–(7) [1]. (1) C O 2 + e − → CO 2 · − E 0 = − 1.9 V (2) C O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e − → CO + H 2 O E 0 = − 0.52 V (3) C O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e − → HCOOH E 0 = − 0.61 V (4) C O 2 + 4 H + + 4 e − → HCHO + H 2 O E 0 = − 0.51 V (5) C O 2 + 6 H + + 6 e − → C H 3 OH + H 2 O E 0 = − 0.38 V (6) C O 2 + 8 H + + 8 e − → C H 4 + 2 H 2 O E 0 = − 0.24 V (7) 2 C O 2 + 12 H + + 12 e − → C 2 H 4 + 4 H 2 O E 0 = − 0.34 V (8) 2 H + + 2 e − → H 2 O E 0 = − 0.42 V However, effective electrochemical reduction of CO2 requires more negative potentials compared to the equilibrium potentials. The reasons are chiefly as follows. Firstly, as shown in Eq. (1), the CO2 molecules are adsorbed onto the surface of the catalyst and transformed into CO 2 · − by electron transfer, which require a large negative potential to break down the stable linear structure of CO2 molecules. Secondly, CO 2 · − is further converted into different reaction intermediates at the surface of the catalyst and desorbed from the surface of the catalyst (Fig. 1 ). During this process, besides overcoming complex kinetics obstacles, the electrolyte system of aqueous solution in the reactor also needs to consume energy to facilitate the mass and electron transport. Thirdly, the electrolytes for most of the CO2 reduction reactions are aqueous solution, which makes hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) a competitive reduction reaction (Eq. (8)). In fact, there are different theoretic mechanisms for various products (C1, C2, C3,…) generated from the CO2RR. For example, the reduction of CO2 to CO proceeds via two-electron transfer process [80]. Firstly, the first electron is transferred to the surface of CO2 molecule to form CO 2 · − radical; then the CO 2 · − radical absorbed on surface of catalysts leads to extra negative charge which promote protonation to form *COOH intermediate (Eq. (9)). Subsequently, further proton-coupled-electron-transfer reactions with *COOH intermediate form CO and one H2O molecule; the CO molecules desorb from the surface of catalysts (Eq. (10)), * denote surface-bound sites. (9) CO 2 · − + H + → * COOH (10) * COOH + e − + H + → CO + H 2 O However, to produce multi-carbon products, the catalyst surface requires strong adsorption capacity for the CO intermediate during CO2 reduction, therefore, it promotes CO further dimerization to generated multi-carbon species via multiple proton-coupled-electron-transfer reactions (Fig. 1) through different reaction intermediates formed on the surface of different electrocatalysts [81–83]. Up to date, there is no advanced technology for detecting the intermediates in situ during CO2 reduction. To further understand the mechanism of CO2 reduction, the design and synthesis of electrocatalysts with high activity, high selectivity and stability is highly desirable. 3 MOFs-based materials for electrochemical reduction of CO2 Owing to their tunable porous structure and properties, a number of MOFs and MOF-derived materials were developed as potential electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction [16,60,61,72,84–87]. To construct MOF materials towards CO2 reduction, selection of suitable metal centers is of importance. So far, numerous metal nodes are developed as the catalytic active sites of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction, such as Ag, Ni, Co, or Cu [61,71,73,88]. For example, Fe, Co, Zn and noble-metal based MOFs materials have been used as electrocatalysts for CO2 conversion to CO [73,87,89], whereas Cu based MOFs materials have also been shown for electrochemistry CO2 reduction to other hydrocarbons such as C2 and C3 [86]. The synthetic methods and chemical composition of MOFs-based catalysts for electrochemistry CO2 reduction have been listed in Table 1 . 3.1 MOF materials To prepare high-performance MOF-based materials for electrocatalytic reduction of CO2, various strategies have been adopted to improve their conductivity, increase the number of exposed surface-active sites, and enhance the stability. One of these strategies is to build MOF-composites as electrocatalysts by in situ growth of MOFs on conductive substrates such as carbon paper, carbon nanotube (CNT), graphene, or modified Al2O3 nanorod [89,90,93,99,107]. The strong interactions between MOFs and substrates contribute to increasing the number of exposed active sites and facilitating the charge transfer from the electrode to catalysts. As a result, the composites exhibit high activity and current density for electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. Another strategy is to fabricate MOF-derived electrocatalysts by means of direct pyrolysis of MOF and MOF-based composites [17,111]. The strategy contributes to the formation of homogeneously distributed metal nanoparticles or/and singe atom throughout the whole skeleton, together with abundant defects within graphitic carbon matrix, which promote the contact between dissolved CO2 and active sites [112–114]. 3.1.1 Iron-based MOF Iron (Fe) can form accessible reduced or oxidized states. Owing to the good chemical stability with Fe(III)-based MOF, they are potential candidates for heterogeneous catalysis. So far, many Fe-based MOFs have been used as photocatalyst for water splitting or dye degradation [36,59,67]. Considering their Lewis acidity and a redox activity [115], Fe-based MOFs are also considered as potential electrocatalysts for CO2 conversion. For example, Hod and co-workers reported the electrophoretic deposition of Fe_MOF-525 thin film on fluorine doped tin oxide (FTO) glass [93]. Through anchoring homogenous catalyst Fe-porphyrins on MOF-525, Fe_MOF-525 presented large accessible active sites (∼1015 sites/cm2). The MOF can electrocatalytic CO2 reduction to the production of CO and H2 in closely equal amount, with ∼100% Faradaic efficiency at a CO2/CO overpotential of about 650 mV. The Faradaic efficiencies for CO and H2 are 54% and 45% without 2,2,2-trifluoroethanol (TFE), respectively. On the contrary, Fe_MOF-525 exhibits slightly improved Faradaic efficiency for CO (60%) in the presence of TFE (Fig. 2 ). They revealed that the Fe(0)-porphyrin species are catalytic active sites for CO2 reduction. The work provides an effective strategy to construct Fe-based MOFs electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction by immobilizing molecular catalysts on MOF. This strategy not only avoids the aggregation and deactivation process of homogeneous molecular catalysts, but also increases the number of catalytic active sites. In order to further improve the performance of Fe-based MOF, introduction of carbon black into porphyrin-based MOF fabricated the composite catalysts PCN-222(Fe)/C. Dong and co-workers observed that the composite catalysts (mass ratio = 1:2) on carbon paper electrode exhibited high catalytic activity for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction to CO with the overpotential of 494 mV [116]. The maximum Faradaic efficiency is 91% toward CO in a CO2-saturated 0.5 M KHCO3 solution. The high performance of the composite PCN-222(Fe)/C could be attributed to the synergistic effects of the single active sites of Fe-porphyrin molecule, the high CO2 adsorption capacity of porous structural MOF, and the improved conductivity from introduced carbon black. Furthermore, the catalyst exhibits high stability after the reaction for 10 h at –0.60 V versus RHE. 3.1.2 Cobalt-based MOFs Like iron, cobalt also exhibits several oxidation states, such as Co(II), Co(III), and Co(IV). It offers a wide field for the creation of Co-based MOF with various coordination geometries including square planar, tetrahedral, pyramidal, and octahedral. As above-mentioned, to achieve electrochemical reduction of CO2, several examples of immobilized cobalt-based MOFs thin film on conductive substrate have been built. They displayed efficiently electrochemistry converting CO2 into CO. As an example, Yang and co-workers in situ fabricated a kind of atomically defined and nanosized cobalt-porphyrin MOFs [89], Al2(OH)2TCPP-Co (TCPP-H2 = 4,4′,4′’,4′’’-(porphyrin-5,10,15,20-tetrayl) tetrabenzoate) atomic layer deposition (ALD) method in microwave reactor. Co-porphyrin MOFs with thickness optimization displayed the excellent activity and selectivity of CO about 76% and retained stability exceed 7 h in controlled potential electrolysis at –0.7 V versus RHE in CO2-saturation buffer. In the low-overpotential region, the MOF composite showed a Tafel slope of 165 mV/decade, implying that one-electron reduction of CO2 to form the CO2 ⋅ radical could be the rate-determining step. To gain deeper insight into the reaction process, in situ spectroelectrochemical measurements were performed on the as-prepared sample for a series of applied potentials and revealed the reduction of CO2 absorbed on a Co porphyrin to CO probably proceeded via Co(I) with a one-electron reduction (Fig. 3 ). The work suggested that the well-defined MOFs with tunable structure provided a good platform to uncover the reaction mechanism of CO2 reduction. The activity of Co-based MOFs can not only be regulated by optimize the catalytic active sites, but also be promoted by modulation of metal nodes. More recently, Lan and co-workers prepared polyoxometalate (POM)-metalloporphyrin organic frameworks (M-PMOF) with hydrothermal method [100]. They tested the electrocatalytic properties toward the CO2RR in CO2-saturated 0.5 M KHCO3 electrolyte and observed that Co-PMOF exhibited remarkable faradaic efficiency (99%) of CO production. The authors attributed the excellent electrocatalytic performance of Co-PMOF electrocatalysts to the synergistic effects of the POM and Co-porphyrin in the CO2 reduction reaction. Further DFT calculations demonstrated Co-PMOF displayed lower adsorbed free energies for the intermediates of *COOH and *CO in rate-determining steps (RDS) for CO2 reduction (Fig. 4 a,b). The cobalt in Co-porphyrin was proposed as a favorable active site whereas POM served as electron-rich aggregates and efficiently promote electronic transport. 3.1.3 Copper-based MOF Cu-MOF materials were first used as electrocatalysts for reduction of CO2 in 2012, Hinogami and co-workers fabricated a copper rubeanate MOF (CR-MOF) by mixing the ethanol solution of rubeanic acid and the aqueous solution of CuSO4 [104]. The authors found that the CR-MOF electrode on carbon paper (CP) showed a highly selective CO2 reduction to HCOOH in 0.5 M KHCO3 solution with a current efficiency of 30% at every potential and a HCOOH selectivity of above 98%. Compared with the Cu metal electrode (Fig. 5 a), the onset potential of CR-MOF electrode was about 0.2 V more positive than the Cu metal electrode under the same conditions. The amount of HCOOH on CR-MOF electrode (13.4 µmol/cm2/h) is 13-fold greater than that on Cu metal electrode (1.1 µmol/cm2/h) at a low potential of –1.2 V versus SHE. The high selectivity of CR-MOF could be attributed to the lower density of electrons on the metallic sites. This structure results in weaker adsorption of CO2 to the CR-MOF, compared with Cu metal electrode (Fig. 5c). The weak adsorption contributes to the production of HCOOH and thus enhances the selectivity of CR-MOF electrode toward HCOOH. However, it remains unclear whether the porous structure affects the activity or/and selectivity of CO2 reduction. Besides the structure of MOF, the solvent also influences the activity and selectivity of CO2 reduction. For instance, Kumar and co-workers investigated the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction of a water stable and porous copper MOF Cu3(BTC)2 with tetra-coordinated Cu site in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) containing tetrabutylammonium tetrafluoroborate (TBATFB) [105]. They demonstrated that Cu3(BTC)2 on glass carbon electrode can effectively catalyze the reduction of CO2 to oxalic acid with 90% purity and the Faradaic efficiency of 51%. The enhanced activity was attributed to the Cu(I) formed adduct with CO2 which promoted the production of oxalic acid (Fig. 6 ). They proposed that the reaction proceeds through two-electron reduction and dimerization process which abstracts proton from non-aqueous solvent DMF to form the oxalic acid. However, investigations of the influence of solvent and ionic liquid on the activity and selectivity of Cu-MOF are further needed. The solvent and electrolytes could affect not only the reaction pathways and the final products, but also the CO2 adsorption capacity of catalysts. Enhancing the CO2 concentration around active sites can help to enable the reactants and products to diffuse efficiently, facilitating the CO2 reduction process. 3.1.4 Zinc-based MOF Zinc (II) with an electronic configuration of [Ar]3d 10 has a completely filled shell orbital and is a borderline hard acid. It readily coordinates with the oxygen, nitrogen or sulfur atoms without a strong preference for organic ligands. Hence, zinc-based metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with different coordination numbers from 4 to 6. Zn-based MOFs have extensively been investigated because of their attractive properties in many potential applications such as gas adsorption and separation, sensing, catalysis, and CO2 capture. Recently, Zn-based MOFs have also been used as catalysts for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. Han and co-workers investigated the CO2 reduction properties of experimental Zn-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (Zn-BTC MOFs) ionic liquids (ILs) electrolytes and revealed that the morphology of MOFs and the type of electrodes influences the current density and selectivity to CH4. Furthermore, they systematically studied the effect of ILs on the CO2 reduction performance [90]. For imidazolium-based ionic liquid, the performance depended on the type of counterion and viscosity of ionic liquid. They proposed that fluorine-containing ionic liquid showed high current density due to its strong interactions with CO2 adsorbed (Fig. 7 a, b). The work demonstrated that the structure and property of the electrolytes affected the reaction pathway as well as the activity and selectivity of the final product. The Zn-MOF plays a role in facilitating electron transfer during CO2 reduction. As Fig. 7(c) shown, during electrolysis the imidazolium cations were firstly absorbed on the surface of Zn-MOF. Then one electron was transferred to CO2 molecule captured by the ILs via conductive Zn-MOF substrates and formed CO 2 · − intermediates. The intermediates take another electron and generate a CO molecule which can be further reduced to CH4 by six electrons due to the stronger absorption capacity of CO than CH4 on the surface of Zn-MOF. The synergistic effect of ILs and Zn-MOF plays a crucial role in highly selective catalyzing CO2 reduction to CH4. In the absence of Zn-MOF, silver electrode in ILs mainly catalyzes reduction of CO2 to CO [117]. In addition to organic electrolyte, it was found that inorganic counterions also affected the activity and selectivity of CO2 reduction on Zn-MOF electrode. Wang and co-workers synthesized a series of Zn-based zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF-8) nanomaterials by introduction of different zinc sources as reactant and investigated the effects of different zinc sources and electrolytes on the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction properties in aqueous solution [91]. They observed that ZIF-8 synthesized using ZnSO4 presented the highest catalytic activity towards CO2 reduction to CO with Faradaic efficiency of 65% at –1.8 V versus Hg/Hg2Cl2 (SCE) (Fig. 8 a). The high activity and selectivity of ZIF-8 having SO4 2− can be attributed to the less interactions between the SO4 2− and Zn nodes, which contributes to facilitating the anion exchange for charge balance when the oxidation state of Zn node is changed. Meanwhile, a decrease in current density was observed with reducing the hydrated anionic radius of the electrolyte (NaCl), along with an increase in faradaic efficiency toward CO2 reduction to CO (Fig. 8b,c). It was proposed that the small hydrated anionic radius contributed to the anion exchange for charge balance and depressed the hydrogen production. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) revealed that ZIF-8 showed a redox peak corresponding to the redox reaction of Zn center (ZnII/ZnI) (Fig. 8d). The metal nodes of ZIF–8 were thus regarded as the electrocatalytic active centers. Notably, this assignment should be carefully confirmed because Zn(II) being a d 10 system has no tendency to enable redox reactions under the current reaction condition. However, the work suggested that with the use of a suitable solvent, the construction of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction on Zn-MOFs was demonstrated to be possible. 3.1.5 Noble-metal-based MOF Like porphyrin-based catalysts, noble-metal-based molecular catalysts displayed high activity and selectivity but they are unstable. Thus, to further enhance the catalytic performance, in general the grafting of molecular catalyst on an electrode is required. For example, it incorporated a molecular catalyst (Fig. 9 a) [92], ReL(CO)3Cl (L = 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid), into highly oriented SURMOF thin films grown on FTO along the [001] direction through liquid-phase epitaxy. The Re-SURMOF-based electrocatalysts display excellent electrocatalytic performance with the high Faradic efficiency of 93% ± 5% for electrocatalytic reducing CO2 to CO. The reduction mechanism was proposed to be two-electron pathway including the reduction of the Re+ center of the [Re(bpy)(CO)3]− to Re0. The superior performance of Re-based MOF was attributed to the high oriented Re-SURMOF with the uniform thickness and a low defect density. Theoretical calculations demonstrate that the orientation of SURMOFs is in favor of charge transport between the interface of electrode and the Re-based redox catalyst (Fig. 9b). So far, considerable silver-based catalysts have been investigated as electrocatalysts for reducing CO2 to CO due to the weak adsorption of CO on the surface of silver catalyst. However, these nanoparticles easily aggregate in large nanoparticles, leading to reducing the accessible active sites. To further improve the performance of silver-based nanomaterials, various strategies were adopted such as tuning the size and shape of nanoparticles. MOFs as a porous material with high specific surface area provide a better platform to construct functional materials, and act as not only a support for immobilization noble-metal molecular catalysts but also a template which promotes the formation of uniform distributed small noble-metal nanoparticles for CO2 reduction. Jiang and co-authors in-situ fabricated Ag2O/zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) composites via one-step hydrothermal treatment of ZIF-7 in AgNO3 aqueous solution (Fig. 10 a) [73]. It was found that small Ag2O nanoparticles were homogenously distributed on ZIF layer with large specific surface area. It was found that Ag2O/ZIF showed more positive onset potential of –0.6 V versus RHE for CO2 reduction than that on the Ag/ZIF-8 in CO2-saturated 0.25 M K2SO4 solution. Compared with ZIF or Ag/C alone, Ag2O/lZIF-8 exhibited the higher CO faradaic efficiency of 80.6% at –1.2 V versus RHE and larger current density. The excellent performance was considered as the synergistic effect of the small size of nanoparticles and high specific surface area (Fig. 10b,c). 3.2 MOF-derived materials MOF derivatives materials have also attracted increasing interest due to the promising electrocatalytic properties [16,89,93,95,118]. Previous reports have pointed out that the metal nodes of MOFs materials act as the active centers for electrocatalytic reduction of CO2, and the electrochemistry performance of MOFs can be regulated by tailoring the structure of catalytic active sites and organic ligands. As to the structure, pristine MOFs are a kind of crystalline materials that consist of flexible metal ions or clusters and organic ligands, which with principle advantages of controllable pore size distribution and high specific surface area. However, the limited conductivity and insufficient structure stability of the pristine MOFs inhibit the development and utilization in electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. Subsequently, MOF-derived materials have been developed as electrocatalysts for reduction of CO2 to overcome the drawbacks of pristine MOFs, which could be fabricated by high temperature treatment. These MOFs-derived carbon based materials including metal nanoparticles or single-atom embedded in in-situ formed graphitic carbon materials exhibited distinct advantages for electrocatalysis reduction of CO2, such as good electronic conductivity, large specific surface area, uniform distributed nanoparticles [7,59,67–69,71–74,88,101,108,119,120], which affected the activity and selectivity of electrochemical CO2 reduction. 3.2.1 MOF-derived nanoparticles as electrocatalysts MOF derived metal nanoparticles have been developed as oxygen reduction reaction, oxygen evolution reaction, hydrogen evolution reaction, and CO2 reduction catalysts. Their catalytic performances to some extent depend on the structure of nanoparticles [59,75]. For example, Guo and co-workers fabricated ZIF-8 derived hybrids materials [98], Pyrolysis of ZIF-8/multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) composites loaded with furfuryl alcohol (FA) (ZIF-CNT-FA-p) acquired metal-free porous carbon nanomaterials. This material displayed high Faradaic efficiency of 100% and current density of 7.7 mA cm−2 at an overpotential of 740 mV. To further improve the performance, iron was introduced into the ZIF-CNT-FA-p composites to form ZIF-Fe-CNT-FA-p. Compare to ZIF-CNT-FA-p, ZIF-Fe-CNT-FA-p demonstrated lower overpotential of 440 mV at a current density of 2 mA cm−2 and a higher CO Faradaic efficiency of 97% (Fig. 11 a–c). The efficient catalytic performance is regarded as the synergistic effect of the intrinsic active sites consisting of the Fe-N x and high content of pyridinic-N in the hybrid as well as the improved electron and mass transport derived from the introduced CNT supports (Fig. 11d,e). However, numerous studies have shown that this type of Fe-N-C materials are often inhomogeneous and contain a large amount of aggregated Fe-based nanoparticles along with atomically-dispersed single-atom Fe components. This complicated material leads to the difficulty of identifying the active sites during catalysis. Recently, Fontecave and co-workers have synthesized a series of Fe-N-C hybrids having a variable ratio of nanoparticles and single-Fe atom to uncover the relationship of the structure and selectivity of the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction [87]. They found that the materials containing sole Fe-N4 moieties displayed highest activity and selectivity toward electrocatalytic CO2 reduction to CO, producing CO with the Faradaic efficiency of above 90%, low overpotential of 190 mV versus RHE, and long-term durability in 0.5 M NaHCO3 aqueous solution. By contrast, the Fe-based materials mainly acted as HER catalysts. A combination of X-ray absorption spectroscopy, electrochemical measurements, and 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy revealed that the selectivity and activity of Fe-N-C toward electrochemical reduction of CO2 to CO can be regulated by changing the ratio of isolated FeN4 and Fe-based nanoparticles. A large number of MOF-derived meta-nitrogen doping carbon hybrids have been investigated for electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. However, they produce majorly C1 products such as CO, HCOOH. Correspondingly, only a few of MOFs are capable of catalyzing reduction of CO2 to multi-carbon products. By contrast, copper-based catalysts are a promising metal material which can further convert CO intermediate into multi-carbon product [7]. For instance, Zhao and co-worker prepared oxide-derived Cu/carbon (OD Cu/C) catalysts via a facile carbonization of Cu-based MOF (HKUST-1). They found that OD Cu/C effectively converted CO2 to methanol and ethanol at lower potential, and proposed the extraordinary performance derived from the coupled interactions between the surficial copper oxides/copper and the matrix of conductive porous carbon [108]. The in situ infrared reflectance (IR) spectroscopy and theoretical calculations revealed that the *CO intermediate was adsorbed on the surface of OD Cu/C catalysts, and then porous carbon supports promoted CC coupling which is a crucial process in the formation of C2 species (Fig. 12 ). In addition, Nam and co-worker also reported another HKUST-1 (MOF)-regulated Cu cluster for electrocatalytic reduction CO2 to C2H4 [86]. They demonstrated that Cu-based catalysts with a low surface Cu coordination number can promote the high selectivity for C2 hydrocarbons, since MOF-derived undercoordinated Cu sites are more active for CC coupling. Therefore, these findings may provide guideline for the design and synthesis of potential catalysts towards electrochemical reduction CO2 to multi-carbon products. 3.2.2 MOF-derived single-atom catalysts So far, various MOFs have been adopted as precursors to fabricate in-situ formed graphitic carbon encapsulated metal nanoparticles as CO2 reduction electrocatalysts [75]. In general, direct pyrolysis of MOF precursors readily forms aggregated metal nanoparticles which show low exposed active sites. To expose the active sites as much as possible, the single atom metal anchored on the carbon matrix by pyrolysis of MOF precursors has been identified as a promising electrocatalyst toward CO2 reduction, due to the high surface area, high conductivity, and the possibility of introducing different heteroatoms (N, P, S and B). So far, various strategies have been adopted to prepare single-atom catalysts by pyrolysis of MOF precursor. Zhao and co-workers reported a new strategy to construct single-atom Ni-based catalysts by introduction of Zn into metal nodes to form bimetal MOFs by exchanging partial Zn nodes with adsorbed Ni ions within the cavity of the ZIF-8 [97]. The strategy avoids the aggregation of Ni species in the hybrid. Finally, a Ni single atom catalyst encapsulated in nitrogen-doped porous carbons (Ni SAs/NC) was synthesized through pyrolysis of the bimetal ZIF-9 for efficient electroreduction of CO2 (Fig. 13 a). Electrochemical CO2 reduction experiments revealed that Ni SAs/NC exhibited an excellent electrocatalytic performance with the current density of 10.48 mA cm−2 at the overpotential of 0.89 V and the Faradaic efficiency of over 71.9% for CO production (Fig. 13h). This designed single-atom catalysts facilitate the mass and electron transfer, because of the large number of exposed reactive active sites. The high performance was considered as the synergistic effect of the increased number of surface-active sites, the strong bonding with CO 2 · − intermediates on single Ni sites, and better electrical conductivity. However, the Ni SAs/NC catalyst displayed a competitive activity toward hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), resulting in unexpected Faradaic efficiency. In order to further improve the performance of ZIF-8 for CO2 reduction, Wang and co-workers developed another strategy to prepare single-atom catalysts with high performance by means of regulating the coordination number of single-atom cobalt [88]. They found that the pyrolysis temperature can effectively affect the coordination number of Co atom. During the pyrolysis, Co/Zn ZIFs broken to release CN fragments at higher temperature, leading to the decrease of CoN bonds (Fig. 14 a). As a result, the single-atom cobalt with two coordinate nitrogen atoms (Co-N2) exhibited the higher electrocatalytic activity and selectivity for reduction of CO2 to CO than the Co center with Co-N4 site (Fig. 14h). The catalyst with Co-N2 sites displayed the best activity and selectivity among these tested samples, with the current density of approximately 18.1 mA cm−2 and the Faradaic efficiency of 94% at a low overpotential of 520 mV in CO2-saturated 0.5 M KHCO3 solution. Experiments and theoretical calculations indicated that the high performance of catalysts with low coordination number was attributed to low charge transfer resistances, low activated energy to form CO 2 · − * intermediates and the strong adsorption capacity of CO 2 · − * on active sites (Fig. 14i). In addition to Co and Ni-based single-atom catalysts, single-atom Fe-based catalysts can also be prepared using ZIF-8 as template through confining Fe species inside the cages of ZIF-8 [72]. Ye and co-worker found that this strategy can avoid the aggregation of iron species and contributes to the formation of isolated single-Fe atom catalysts due to the confinement effect of ZIF-8. The isolated single-Fe atom catalysts displayed high activity and selectivity of CO2 reduction in KHCO3 solution compared with the Fe-base nanoparticles. Furthermore, the performance of single-atom catalysts is also dependent of the synthesis method of single-atom catalysts. The single-atom Fe species confined on the surface of the ZIF-8 provided more exposed isolated Fe-N active sites compared with the single-atom Fe confined in the cage of ZIF-8, which contributed to high CO Faradaic efficiency and current density toward CO2 reduction. To further understand the mechanism of CO2 reduction on Fe-N-C catalysts, a combination of experimental and theoretical computations would be effective method to further clarify the reaction pathway on the M-N4 sites. Pan and co-worker demonstrated that both Fe-N-C and Co-N-C single-atom catalysts can effectively catalyze the reduction of CO2 to CO, while the Fe-N-C catalysts displayed the highest CO Faradaic efficiency of 93% at an overpotential 0.47 V among the as-prepared samples [111]. The experimental observations together with theoretical calculations revealed that the high activity and selectivity toward CO2 reduction were attributed to the edge-hosted M-N2+2-C8 sites which bridge in situ formed two armchair-like graphitic layers. The metal centers having dangling bonds neighbor to N are the real active sites which absorb the intermediates ∗CO and ∗OH after the cleavage of CO bond during catalysis. 4 Conclusions and outlooks In this review, we summarized and discussed an overview of progress about different strategies used to prepare MOF-based electrocatalysts for the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. Pristine MOFs materials were often used as the electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction, which exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity and selectivity due to the tunable metal nodes and organic linkers. Compared with homogeneous molecular catalysts, heterogeneous MOFs not only possess the merits of molecular catalysts and heterogeneous porous catalysts, but also display the periodic arrangement of organic ligands and metal notes. This type of molecular heterogeneous catalysts is helpful for understanding the relationship between the structure and properties at the molecular level. So far, different MOFs have been developed as electrocatalysts for electrochemical reduction of CO2. However, only a few of MOFs exhibited electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. Furthermore, most of reports mainly focused on metal-porphyrin MOFs due to their unique square plane coordinated geometry, which favors the CO2 adsorption on active sites. On the other hand, owing to the improved electron transfer and mass transport, MOF-derived materials have been developed as electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction which exhibited unprecedented electrocatalytic activity, selectivity. Various strategies have been employed to fabricate MOF-derived nanocarbon hybrids for application in electrocatalytic CO2 reduction, but the MOF precursors reported are mainly imidazolate-containing ZIF materials. Although most of MOFs and MOF-derived electrocatalysts have been shown promising performance, great challenges remain to develop MOFs and MOF-derived catalysts with high activity and selectivity toward electrochemical reduction of CO2. Firstly, only a few of non-precious metal active centers are available to construct MOF-based catalysts including Fe, Co, Ni, Zn, and Cu. Other non-precious metals could also be introduced into MOF, such as Sn, Mo, and W which are considered as promising active centers for CO2 reduction [121]. Secondly, MOFs and MOF-derived materials were focused on single metal used as metal active sites. Development of mixed metal-based catalysts could contribute to understand the reaction mechanism of CO2 reduction through regulating the electronic structure, the d-band centre, and surface charge density of metal centers by incorporation of second active or inactive metal [46]. Thirdly, besides porphyrin- and ZIF-based MOFs, more efforts are needed to design and synthesize different types of MOFs which provide more opportunities to search the potential MOF-based electrocatalysts with high activity and selectivity toward CO2 reduction. Additionally, limited research has been reported on the utilization of MOF with different morphologies for CO2 reduction, such as ultrathin two-dimensional nanosheet, nanowire, and nanocage. These unique morphologies could facilitate the electronic transfer and mass transport during electrocatalysis. Fourth, the products of MOF-based catalysts reported are main C1 chemical such as CO and HCOOH. It is well known that Cu-based catalysts are potential candidates towards converting carbon dioxide to multi-carbon chemical [7,122,123]. However, the efficiency and selectivity of CO2 reduction over Cu-based MOF materials still remain a lot of room for improvement. To obtain higher Faraday efficiency of multi-carbon products, the rational design and synthesis of Cu-based MOFs materials is highly desirable such as constructing single-atom Cu-based catalysts and adjusting the coordination geometry of Cu sites. Fifth, although the reported MOF-based materials demonstrated the electrochemical stability by a constant current method, the recyclability of the MOF-based materials is scarcely discussed. The surface and bulky structures of MOF-based materials after long-term test should be further investigated by a wide range of characterizations, such as X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). Notably, XRD measurements reflect the bulky structure of materials, and cannot provide accurate information about the surface structure of materials which is a crucial for photo- and electro-catalysts. On the contrast, HRTEM is an effective method to govern the structural changes in the surface and interface of catalysts [124]. Sixth, although single-atom catalysts derived from MOFs exhibit excellent CO2 reduction performance, this type of catalysts probably face the diffusivity of sub-nanometer species and high mobility. Thus, further efforts are needed to develop effective strategies for design and synthesis of single-atom catalysts with controllable structure anchoring single-atom active sites. Finally, mechanistic understanding of CO2 electroreduction is of great importance to design and prepare high-performance catalysts. A combination of theoretical calculations and in-situ experimental technologies is an effectively approach to exploring the intermediates and reveal the structural change of catalysts during electrocatalysis. These knowledges are helpful for rational design of new catalysts and avoiding a large amount of trial-and-error experiments. In summary, creation of stable high-performance MOF-based electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction is still a significant challenge. Hopefully, the recent progress on MOF-based materials for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction could not only promote the development of the MOFs in the field of energy conversion, but also provide clues to design and synthesis of functional MOF-based materials for CO2 reduction. Yamada D.G. Nocera Shao-Horn Y. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 134 2012 16959 16962 Ping Shao received her M.S. degree from Nanchang Hangkong University in 2018. From 2016 to 2018, she studied as a jointly student in Prof. Zhenhai Wen's group at the Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences. She is currently working as a research assistant in Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Her research is focused on electrochemical functional materials and their application in energy storage and conversion. Luocai Yi received his B.S. degree (2014) and M.S. degree (2018) in Jingdezhen Ceramic Institute and Nanchang Hangkong University, respectively. Since July 2016, he studied as a jointly student in Prof. Zhenhai Wen's group at the Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences. He is pursuing his Ph.D. degree in FJIRSMCAS. His current research focuses on the design and the synthesis of nano-materials and their applications, such as desalination, photothermal conversion, photoelectrocatalysis, and device design and fabrication. Mechanics and electronics are his hobbies.

coredata.dc:description: Direct electrochemical reduction of CO2 into valuable chemicals and fuel is one of the most promising approaches to address the current energy crisis and lower CO2 emission. Recently, numerous metal-organic framework (MOF) and their derived materials have extensively been developed as electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction owing to their unique structure including porosity, large specific surface area, and tunable chemical structures. In this review, the recent progress of MOF-based electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction was summarized and discussed. Detailed discussions mainly focus on the synthesis and mechanism of pristine MOFs and MOF-derived materials for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. These examples are expected to provide clues to rational design and synthesis of stable and high-performance MOFs-based electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction.

coredata.dc:title: Metal-organic frameworks for electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide: The role of metal centers
